choices.text: Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus
Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors associated with recurrent seizures EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Risk factors associated with recurrent seizures are
•    Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus
•    Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis
•    Strong family history of seizures
•    An abnormal focal  neurologic examination
•    An abnormal EEG

questions.text: A 47year old man was brought by his wife to casualty. He had been hallucinating that morning seeing three dogs run across his living floor and four small children in kitchen. Such formed visual hallucinations may occur in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Temporal lobe pathology.

Visual hallucinations can occur with lesions anywhere within the visual system but formed visual hallucinations of people, animals and objects often occur with diseases affecting the temporal lobes or in diffuse Lewy body disease.

Occipital lobe epilepsy tends to cause unformed images that are usually patterns.

Migrainous aura is associated with fortification spectra and lights that move across visual field.

choices.text: Jacksonian epilepsy is spreading seizure activity.
Serum level of prolactin increases dramatically after tonic clonic convulsions.
Changes in memory/perception and blackouts are not features of focal seizure with impaired awareness.
Absence seizures are briefer and more frequent without post ictal confusion .

questions.text: The following statement are true about epilepsy except :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Changes in memory/perception and blackouts are not features of focal seizure with impaired awareness.

Complex partial seizure are characterized by focal seizure activity with transient unconsciousness beginning with an aura. Behavioural arrest or motionless stare denotes beginning of ictal phase which marks the onset of period of amnesia & automatisms. Following seizure anterograde amnesia ,confusion and post ictal aphasia is present.

questions.text: Ratio of drug concentration in breast milk relative to serum is minimal  with which of the following antiepileptic drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Valproate.

Antiepileptic medications are excreted into breast milk to a variable degree. The ratio of drug concentration in breast milk relative to serum ranges from 5% (valproic acid) to 300% (levetiracetam). Given the overall benefits of breast-feeding and the lack of evidence for long-term harm to the infant by being exposed to antiepileptic drugs, mothers with epilepsy can be encouraged to breast-feed. This should be reconsidered, however, if there is any evidence of drug effects on the infant such as lethargy or poor feeding.

choices.text: Ability to suppress seizure activity for more than 24 hours after one injection.
Rapid onset of action after intravenous administration.

questions.text: Most physicians recommend using high dose of intravenous benzodiazepine as part of management of status epilepticus because it has which of the following qualities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rapid onset of action after intravenous administration.

At one time the most popular benzodiazepine for use in status epilepticus was diazepam, which has rapid onset of action in the brain, but is redistributed in the body relatively quickly. Because of this property ,patients needed additional medication to protect themselves from recurrent seizure activity as early as 20 minutes after diazepam injection .A less fat soluble benzodiazepine, lorazepam, has advantage of acting rapidly but being cleared ore slowly from the brain.

questions.text:
In treatment of epilepsy ,sodium valproate :-
1).Is the drug of choice in pregnant women.
2).Can cause weight loss.
3).No blood tests are required to screen for liver abnormalities.
4).Can cause hirsutism.
5).Is usually the drug of choice in primary generalized epilepsy.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

5 only. 

Sodium valproate has a high incidence of teratogenicity and should be avoided in women of child bearing age. A screen of LFT is requisite as valproate can be hepatotoxic.Weight gain is also a common problem with it. Phenytoin & carbamazepine can cause hirsutism but valproate causes hair loss. It is usually the drug of choice for primary generalized epilepsy.

questions.text: A 28 year old female primigravida 2 months pregnant known case of JME off any AED presently presented with an episode of GTCS preceded by multiple episodes of myoclonus .Which of the following would be best to start her therapy ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

LEVETRIACETAM.

The drug of first choice in the treatment of JME is sodium valproate, which has a response rate of up to 80%. Valproate should be avoided in women of childbearing age because of significantly increased risks of fetal malformations and neurodevelopmental delay. Levetiracetam or lamotrigine are alternative first-line options if valproate is contraindicated.

There has been some studies suggesting lamotrigine could exacerbate myoclonus so Levetiracetam could be an ideal choice for the patient.

questions.text: Coarse tremors in tongue are seen in all except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Thyrotoxicosis.

Coarse tremors is defined as slow 4-6 per second. 

Causes are :-
A. Parkinsonism.
B. Wilson disease and other extrapyramidal syndromes.
C. Delirium tremens.
D. General paresis (seen in neurosyphillis 10-30 years after primary syphilis )
E. Cerebellar tremors.

questions.text: Diagnose the following movement disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Athetosis 

This movement depicts slow,sinous ,writhing movement like a crawling movement in the distal extremity suggestive of ATHETOSIS.

questions.text: Match the following Gait disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

questions.text: A 79 year old male presents to his doctor after his wife noticed that he had slowed down and his posture has changed in that he has bent over. The following would support a diagnosis of Parkinson disease :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shuffling gait.

Spasticity is a feature of hypertonia associated with upper motor neuron lesions and is not a feature of PD. Rigidity ,either lead pipe or cogwheel ,is the form of hypertonia associated with PD. Supranuclear vertical gaze palsies in the context of parkinsonism tend to occur with progressive supranuclear palsy. The tremor is pill rolling rest tremor, not a postural tremors.

questions.text: Which of the following is most useful in the diagnosis of parkinsonism :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Diagnosis of PD is always made on the basis of clinical symptoms coupled with a good clinical examination.

choices.text: LRRK 2 gene mutation is on chromosome number 21.
Mutation of parkin gene is associated with Parkinson disease below 40 years.
Alpha synuclein mutation is related to chromosome 4.

questions.text: All of the following about familial Parkinsonism are true except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

LRRK 2 gene mutation is on chromosome number 21.

About 10–15% of cases are familial in origin, and multiple specific mutations and gene associations have been identified
Six different LRRK2 mutations have been linked to PD is due to mutation on chromosome number 12.
Mutations in α-synuclein via chromosome number 4  cause rare familial forms of PD, and α-synuclein constitutes the major component of Lewy bodies in patients with sporadic PD
Mutations in PINK1 and parkin have implicated mitochondrial dysfunction as a possible cause of PD.
Mutations in the parkin gene should be considered in patients with onset prior to 40 years of age.

choices.text: A 64 year old woman on levodopa –carbidopa who continues to experience episode of freezing while walking.
A 68 year old man with recurrent falls due to orthostatic hypotension.
A 70 year old woman with severe tremor unresponsive to therapy.
A 71 year old man with worsening symptoms of dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with Parkinson disease is the best candidate for deep brain stimulation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A 70 year old woman with severe tremor unresponsive to therapy.

Most surgical procedures for PD performed today utilize deep brain stimulation (DBS). Here, an electrode is placed into the target area and connected to a stimulator inserted SC over the chest wall. DBS simulates the effects of a lesion without necessitating a brain lesion. 

The procedure is thus primarily indicated for patients who suffer disability resulting from levodopa-induced motor complications that cannot be satisfactorily controlled with drug manipulation. Another indication is intractable tremors not responding to anticholinergics.

choices.text: A cervical myelopathy secondary to cervical spondylosis.
A right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke.

questions.text: Following clinical sign is unilateral in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is associated with bilateral degeneration of both upper and lower motor neurons.Any cause of myelopathy will usually cause bilateral extensor plantar responses.Multiple sclerosis is associated with diffuse white matter involvement which often involves both corticospinal tracts at some point in their long pathway.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented with complaint of a fogging of vision in the left eye which he described as a “curtain doming down”. It lasted a minute before returning to normal. There were no other symptoms. The following is the most likely cause of his visual impairment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carotid embolism.

Amaurosis fugax is transient visual loss caused by a blockage of the ophthalmic artery or its branches to the retina. It can occur due to carotid embolism.

Retinitis pigmentosa causes progressive visual loss which usually starts in the peripheral visual field and spreads to involve central vision.

Papilledema due to raised intracranial pressure can also cause progressive visual loss starting at the periphery.

choices.text: Total left middle cerebral artery infarction.
Lacunar infarction of the internal capsule.
Partial left middle cerebral artery infarction.

questions.text: A 74-year-old hypertensive man developed an acute onset severe weakness in his right side involving his arm & leg. On examination, he has a right hemiplegia with no sensory loss. Which of the following lesion best explains his deficit:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lacunar infarction of the internal capsule.

Pure motor loss is due to lacunar infarction of internal capsule due to infarction of lenticulostriate branches of MCA.

Due to partial or total MCA infarction sensory loss is seen with motor weakness.

choices.text: Total left middle cerebral artery infarction.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman was involved in a car accident and suffered a severe whiplash injury but was otherwise well. The following day she presents to casualty with weakness on her right side, confusion and incomprehensible speech. On examination she has a left sided Horner’s syndrome, right hemiplegia and right homonymous hemianopia. Unfortunately, she became drowsy and obtunded over the next 24 hours and dies. 
Which of the following lesion best explains her disorder:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Internal carotid artery occlusion.

Complete carotid occlusion can be fatal due to post infarction edema. In this case left carotid artery dissection following a declaration car accident car accident and sympathetic fibers are involved due to carotid dissection.

Middle cerebral artery infarction would occur due to internal carotid occlusion but Horner’s syndrome will not happen due to MCA occlusion.

Internal capsule infarction will have motor symptoms only.

Cerebellar hemorrhage is post HTN bleed, will present predominantly with cerebellar symptoms.

questions.text: A 72 year old right handed man was admitted to the stroke unit.A CT brain scan performed identified an infarct in right middle cerebral artery  territory .The following signs typically occur with non dominant cortical lesions :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dressing apraxia.

The dominant cerebral cortex is on the left in the majority of right handed people is specifically involved in readindg,maths(dyscalculia),writing and language.Apraxias involving visulospatial tasks,e.g . dressing and drawing shapes is a symptom of dysfunction in the non dominant lobe .More subtle functions of the dominant parietal lobe include naming fingers (If abnormal this is called a finger agnosia ) and left to right discrimination.

choices.text: Posterior communicating artery aneurysm with SAH
Anterior communicating Artery aneurysm with SAH

questions.text: 46 yr old patient complaining of severe bursting headache on examination he was found to be conscious but restless, neck stiffness & drooping of right eyelid were observed. Clinical diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


3rd nerve palsy,posterior communicating artery & 3rd nerve are in close relation.

Headache suggest SAH

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman develops acute onset weakness in the right side of her face & right arm with slurring of speech. She is assessed within 90 minutes of symptom onset and deemed a candidate for thrombolysis.
What is the single most appropriate next action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT brain.


A CT scan of the brain is needed to exclude hemorrhagic stroke first, which would contraindicate thrombolysis. Alteplase therapy would follow if it is not a hemorrhagic stroke. MRI is not performed to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CONDUCTION APHASIA.

Conduction aphasia comes from lesions of the superior temporal lobe or the inferior parietal region, and is marked by inability to repeat, with relatively preserved speech production (aside from mild paraphasic errors) and preserved speech comprehension. Due to the surrounding anatomical structures, symptoms that often accompany conduction aphasia include apraxia of the left side, right hemiparesis, right sensory loss, or right-sided hemianopsia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man has a subarachnoid hemorrhage. His GCS is 13. CT angiogram confirms presence of a middle cerebral artery aneurysm with normal sized ventricles. He suddenly becomes comatose (GCS 3) with fixed dilated pupils. What is the single most likely cause of his symptoms.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Re rupture.

Any sudden drop in level of consciousness in a patient with aneurysmal SAH is suggestive of rebleed of aneurysm due to re rupture.

Prescence of normal sized ventricles makes hydrocephalus unlikely.

Hyponatremia does not occur in the acute phase of SAH or cause a fixed dilated pupil.

Similarly, vasospasm occurs 4-14 days after SAH unlikely in acute phase.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man’s wife suddenly noticed his slurring of speech and right arm weakness which completely resolved in 30 minutes. He has a history of diabetes. His blood pressure is normal. Which of the following best represents his ABCD2 score.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5
                                       ABCD2 SCORING SYSTEM

questions.text: Sensation tested by following instrument exhibits maximum sensitivity in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Finger pads.

Two point discrimination is the ability to discern that two nearby objects touching the skin  are truly twopoints,not one.Maximum sensitivity is in lips and finger tips .

Body areas differ both in tactile receptor density and somatosensory cortical representation. Normally, a person should be able to recognize two points separated by 2 to 8 mm on fingertips. On the lips, it is 2 to 4 mm, and on the palms, it is 8 to 12 mm and 30–40 mm on the shins or back (assuming the points are at the same dermatome). The posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway is responsible for carrying information involving fine, discriminative touch. Therefore, two-point discrimination can be impaired by damage to this pathway or to a peripheral nerve.

choices.text: It is a microtubule associated protein.
Functions to assemble and stabilize microtubules.
In Alzheimer’s disease ,it is hypo phosphyrylated.
Progressive supranuclear palsy may represent a tau pathologic process.

questions.text: Tau proteins is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Alzheimer’s disease ,it is hypo phosphyrylated

Tau is a microtubule associated protein that assembles & stabilizes microtubules that convey cell organelles,glycoprotein through neuron.A hyperphosphyrylated state of tau impairs its capacity to bind to microtubules.

questions.text:
A patient suffering wi with Alzheimer has great difficulty in completing this task . 
Which of the following symptom is shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Apraxia.

In the image shown patient has great difficulty in wearing a pant which means he may require assistance suggestive of  dressing apraxia.

choices.text: Terminally ill patients taking morphine for analgesia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female was applying her make up one morning when she noticed the right eye appeared different and the pupil appeared much larger than that in the left eye. A large pupil may be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

lesion in the midbrain.

A lesion in midbrain causes an enlarged pupil.

Horner’s syndrome results from damage to the sympathetic syndrome results from damage to the sympathetic fibers to the pupil and includes miosis .

Opiates cause meiosis. Pontine lesions cause pin point pupils.

choices.text: Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: The following may cause a third nerve palsy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe.

Herniation of the uncus through the tentorial hiatus commonly cause third nerve compression due to raised supratentorial pressure.
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension often causes papilledema.

Multiple sclerosis can cause optic neuritis.

Pancoast tumor often infiltrates the lower part of brachial plexus and causes weakness & wasting of the hand in association with Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: Sensory loss of this pattern would be seen in which of the following disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Syringomyelia.

In the image shown it’s a typical CAPE Like distribution of sensory loss typical of syringomyelia as it commonly affects lower cervical and upper thoracic segements of spinal cord which supply the shoulder region extending into upper limb .

ALS,GBS don’t have sensory loss.

In DM  we have got glove and stocking kind of sensory loss.

choices.text: Loss of pinprick sensation over web space between first and second digits of left foot.
Hyperreflexia at the left knee jerk.

questions.text: A 46 year old male has lower back pain radiating down to posterior aspect of his left leg and paraesthesia in the lateral aspect of left foot.Strength and bowel functions have been normal.Examination is likely to show which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyporeflexia in the ankle jerk.

History is suggestive of S1 raddiculopathy secondary to disc prolapse  in which loss of ankle jerk is an early feature with loss sensation over 4 & 5 th web space over the foot.Minimal motor weakness is seen with intact bowel and bladder functions.

questions.text: The following clinical sign would be positive if the lesion is BELOW.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

T10.

Beevor’s sign is characteristic of spinal cord injury between T10 and T12 levels. This occurs when the upper part of the Rectus abdomininal  muscle is intact but the lower part is weak because of the spinal injury. Thus when the patient is asked to raise his head as he lies supine on bed, only the upper part of the muscle contracts pulling the umbilicus toward the head.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented with increasing weakness over his right arm & leg with loss of vibration and joint position sense in the right arm & leg and loss of pin prick in the left arm & leg. Which of the following investigation would be useful to secure the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
MRI of cervical spinal cord.

The clinical profile of the patient is suggestive of hemi section of spinal cord-Brown Sequard syndrome. In this case it involves arms, so we would need an MRI of the cervical spine.

Nerve conduction study would be helpful in diagnosis of neuropathy which would unlikely cause hemiparesis & differential involvement of sensory loss.

Lumbar puncture would only have a supportive role for finding the etiology like TBM leading to spinal vasculitis.

MRI brain would have been helpful if patient had clinical symptoms suggestive of stroke causing hemiparesis with complete hemisensory on the same side of weakness.

questions.text: Following test would be positive in which condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tabes Dorsalis.

Tabes dorsalis is a lesion affecting the posterior column.

This test performed is Romberg test.

choices.text: Root pain or midine back pain

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of extramedullary tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


EXTRAMEDULLARY TUMOUR:
•    Early corticospinal signs and paralysis 
•    Root pain or midine back pain 
•    Asymmetric weakness
Early Sacral involvement

choices.text: Weakness of shoulder abduction and elbow extension.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs may be found in thoracic myelopathy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sensory level on the trunk.

In a thoracic myelopathy there will be no wasting or fasiculations. A spastic paraparesis (increased tone) will develop pyramidal distribution weakness in the legs (but not the arms, as the arms are innervated by the cervical spine) and brisk reflexes in the lower limbs with extensor plantar.

A sensory level may extend onto trunk.

choices.text: More common in male than female
Death of posterior horn cell neurons
Death of neurons in motor cortex in cerebral hemisphere

questions.text: All of the following are features of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


In ALS the death of the peripheral motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord leads to denervation and consequent atrophy of the corresponding muscle fibers. Histochemical and electrophysiologic evidence indicates that in the early phases of the illness denervated muscle can be reinnervated by sprouting of nearby distal motor nerve terminals, although reinnervation in this disease is considerably less extensive than in most other disorders affecting motor neurons (e.g., poliomyelitis, peripheral neuropathy). 
As denervation progresses, muscle atrophy is readily recognized in muscle biopsies and on clinical examination. This is the basis for the term amyotrophy.
 The loss of cortical motor neurons results in thinning of the corticospinal tracts that travel via the internal capsule  and brainstem to the lateral and anterior white matter columns of the spinal cord. The loss of fibers in the lateral columns and resulting fibrillary gliosis impart a particular firmness (lateral sclerosis). A remarkable feature of the disease is the selectivity of neuronal cell death.
 By light microscopy, the entire sensory apparatus, the regulatory mechanisms for the control and coordination of movement, remains intact. Except in cases of frontotemporal dementia, the components of the brain required for cognitive processing are also preserved. 
Motor neurons required for ocular motility remain unaffected, as do the parasympathetic neurons in the sacral spinal cord (the nucleus of Onufrowicz, or Onuf ) that innervate the sphincters of the bowel and bladder.

questions.text:
A dissociated pattern of sensory loss may be seen in:
1). Compression of the spinal cord by a prolapsed interverbal disc. 
2). Anterior spinal artery occlusion.
3). Brown Sequard syndrome.
4). Syringomyelia.
5). Tabes dorsalis.
Select the correct answer using the code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2, 4 and 5.

Dissociated sensory loss is a pattern of neurological damage caused by a lesion to a single tract in the spinal cord which involves selective loss of vibration and proprioception without loss of pain & temperature or VICE VERSA.
In syringomyelia & anterior spinal artery occlusion there is dissociated loss of pain & temperature sensation but the dorsal columns (vibration & proprioception) are spared. 
In Tabes dorsalis there is dissociated loss of dorsal column sensation with sparing of spinothalamic sensations.
A prolapsed intervertebral disc compressing the spinal cord will cause a myelopathy and affect all modalities.
In brown Sequard syndrome there is hemi section of spinal cord with involvement of both spinothalamic & posterior column sensation on one side.

choices.text: Thymectomy is indicated in the absence of thymoma
Immunosuppressants like azathioprine are used only in myesthenic crisis
MuSK positive patients go into complete remission with thymectomy

questions.text: The patient with generalized myasthenia gravis shows improvement in ocular weakness on receiving edrophonium which of the following statement is true about the treatment of the  patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thymectomy is indicated in the absence of thymoma 

Thymectomy is indicated in all generalised myasthenia except those with MuSK antibody,ocular MG , avoidable in <15,>55 years age group. 

They have poorer response to thymectomy. Early treatment with immunosupressants is helpful not only restricted to myaesthenic crisis.

Pyridostigmine is DOC to start the treatment of MG.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct in respect of Myasthenia gravis?
1. Symptoms worsen towards the end of the day
2. There may be difficulty in chewing and swallowing
3. Acetylcholine receptors in the pre-junctional membrane involved
4. Penicillamine may precipitate similar illness

Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1, 2 and 4.

In MG, the fundamental defect is a decrease in the number of available AChRs at the postsynaptic muscle membrane. In addition, the postsynaptic folds are flattened, or “simplified.” These changes result in decreased efficiency of neuromuscular transmission. Therefore, although ACh is released normally, it produces small end plate potentials that may fail to trigger muscle action potentials.

Cardinal features of myasthenia gravis are weakness and fatigability of muscles. The weakness increases during repeated use (fatigue) or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.

Weakness in chewing is most noticeable after prolonged effort, as in chewing meat.

Penicillamine can exacerbate or precipitate Myasthenic weakness.

choices.text: Worsening with coughing ,sneezing or bending over.
Better on waking first thing in the morning and worse on standing.

questions.text: The headache of raised intracranial pressure is typically associated with :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Worsening with coughing ,sneezing or bending over.
Coughing, sneezing and bending overall increase intracranial pressure and worsen the headache.Fortification spectra are typical of aura associated with migraine headache.Patients with raised pressure often have dull,progressive headache.The headache is worse on waking in the morning and on prolonged lying flat and better with standing in contrast to low pressure headaches seen after LP.

choices.text: Aspirin, domperidone during attack, no prophylactic therapy.
Rizatriptan, domperidone during attack, no prophylactic therapy.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman has unilateral throbbing headaches associated with nausea & photophobia. They occur once per month around her menses and she sleeps them off in a dark room. She has not tried any medications. She wants to be pregnant in the future.
Which is the single best initial treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rizatriptan ,domperidone during attack  ,no prophylactic therapy.

Rizatriptan with domperidone during attack is more effective than NSAIDS. Since her attacks are infrequent (<4 attacks/month), prophylactic therapy is best to be avoided.

questions.text: Diagnosis of migraine is supported by :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Associated nausea ,vertigo and photophobia.

Chronic form of tension type headache occurs most days in the month unlike migraine which tends to occur periodically.There should be no loss of counciousness.Standing helps headache with raised intracranial pressure.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old overweight has 2 months of increasing frontal throbbing headaches. They are worse on lying down and coughing. She has markedly reduced peripheral vision. A CT head & CT venogram are normal. Lumbar puncture shows a very high opening pressure if 42 cm of water.
What is the single best initial action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Start acetazolamide.

This headache has postural features and high opening pressure on lumbar puncture confirms raised intracranial pressure. Scans exclude mass lesions & venous thrombosis. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is the most likely diagnosis and is most common in young obese women. Immediate treatment should be to start Acetazolamide followed by LP shunting, if there is no improvement.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female was brought by her daughter complaining of a new and persistent headache for 2 weeks that would awake her from her sleep. She felt persistently nauseated and drowsy through the day. Her CT scan showed hydrocephalus. In this case the most likely explanation for hydrocephalus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tuberculous meningitis.

Any process that causes a blockage in the passage of CSF between the choroid plexus and arachnoid plexus and arachnoid granulations can cause hydrocephalus. Basal meningitis caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis and some fungi which can block the passage of CSF.
Idiopathic or benign intracranial hypertension does not have hydrocephalus.
Subarachnoid hemorrhage rather than subdural hemorrhage can cause blockage of the arachnoid granulations or basal cisterns.

choices.text: Inform patient that he has entered progressive course.
MRI brain with contrast and lumbar puncture.
Prescribe steroids then give next natalizumab infusion.
Switch to an alternative drug due to failure of natalizumab.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male has relapsing type of multiple sclerosis and has developed progressive left arm weakness and numbness over 3 weeks. He has monthly natalizumab infusions. What is the next most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MRI brain with contrast and lumbar puncture.

Suspected relapse or slowly progressive symptoms on Natalizumab needs investigation to exclude progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) which is caused by the JC virus. MRI with contrast will show new lesions and if patient has PML there will be JC viral DNA in the CSF.

A progression over 3 weeks is quite long for a relapse and needs investigating rather than treating with steroids. Progression cannot be accepted without excluding PML.

choices.text: The infectious particles are easily destroyed by conventional sterilization techniques.
Have a quicker clinical progression in the new variant than the sporadic form.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about prion disease :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Can be genetically inherited.

Prion diseases are caused by a novel infectious agent called prion;prions are abnormally conformed proteins that do not contain RNA and DNA.The infectious particle is highly resistant to all usual methods of sterilisation and requires special techniques to inactivate it.Surgical instruments used on an infected prion disease patient therefore should not be used again.There are several forms of inherited prion disease but most are sporadic with no known cause.There has  been a link between prion disease affecting cows known as bovine spongioform encephalopathy and a new variant of a human form known as new variant Creutzfled Jakob diasease or nv CJD.This form is slower in onset than the sporadic form and often presents with psychiatric features and myoclonus.

questions.text: Which is not seen in Miller Fischer syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Postural hypotension.
Miller Fischer syndrome is defined by Ataxia,Areflexia and external opthalmoplegia(s/o cranial nerve palsy).90% of these patients are seropositive for antibodies GQ1b.
Postural hypotension is usually an autonomic involvement seen in GBS in which ascending paralysis can cause involvement f T4- 8 sympathetic outflow to the heart.

questions.text: A lesion of the lateral medulla on one side may give rise to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Horner’s syndrome.
Involvement of sympathetic trunk can give rise to a Horner’s syndrome.
Ipsilateral facial sensory loss occurs due to involvement of trigeminal spinal nucleus not facial weakness.
The nucleus ambigus is involved in lateral medullary lesions causing ipsilateral palatal weakness. 
Hypoglossal nucleus is a paramedian structure in the medulla and is therefore not affected in lateral lesion.

questions.text: Which type of multiple sclerosis is depicted in the following image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Relapsing remitting type(RRMS).
